snippet.textDisplay: This would be my favorite Zelda if only it had more damn Dungeons and Temples. It feels half finished and hardly a major Zelda title.
snippet.textOriginal: This would be my favorite Zelda if only it had more damn Dungeons and Temples. It feels half finished and hardly a major Zelda title.

snippet.textDisplay: Just got the re-release on Wii U - I forgot just how beautiful this game is! Agreed about the disappointing dungeons. For me, it wasn't so much that they were disappointing, but that there were so damn FEW of them. Also, while I absolutely love sailing around the ocean, and the accompanying theme, it felt like there should have been more than one ocean theme (similar to the point you made in the Earthbound post about it being frustrating when RPGs only have one battle theme, even if it's great).
snippet.textOriginal: Just got the re-release on Wii U - I forgot just how beautiful this game is! Agreed about the disappointing dungeons. For me, it wasn't so much that they were disappointing, but that there were so damn FEW of them. Also, while I absolutely love sailing around the ocean, and the accompanying theme, it felt like there should have been more than one ocean theme (similar to the point you made in the Earthbound post about it being frustrating when RPGs only have one battle theme, even if it's great).

snippet.textDisplay: Hmm...dungeons were always my least favorite part of Zelda games, which is probably why this one was my favorite.

snippet.textDisplay: Short isn't necessarily bad, they can put more thought into what already exists. Majora's Mask was short and yet was brilliant due to deep level design and tons of side quests wheras WW has good dungeons, varied gameplay, and a large world to explore.
snippet.textOriginal: Short isn't necessarily bad, they can put more thought into what already exists. Majora's Mask was short and yet was brilliant due to deep level design and tons of side quests wheras WW has good dungeons, varied gameplay, and a large world to explore.

snippet.textDisplay: Yes! I agree. I loved everything about Wind Waker but I always dread that Triforce quest. If they added more dungeons for the Triforce pieces instead, this would be even more amazing.
snippet.textOriginal: Yes! I agree. I loved everything about Wind Waker but I always dread that Triforce quest. If they added more dungeons for the Triforce pieces instead, this would be even more amazing.

snippet.textDisplay: Yeah, but most people wouldn't right away unless they already knew they were virtually required to complete the game.
snippet.textOriginal: Yeah, but most people wouldn't right away unless they already knew they were virtually required to complete the game.

snippet.textDisplay: I thought the triforce fetch quest was a good idea in theory as a way of mixing it up with some mini dungeons rather than throwing more main dungeons at us, and to pay homage to the original Zelda. It wasn't executed all that well for the reasons you gave, though your "rupee hoardings" criticism doesn't become an issue if you find all of the rupee bag upgrades as soon as they become available.
snippet.textOriginal: I thought the triforce fetch quest was a good idea in theory as a way of mixing it up with some mini dungeons rather than throwing more main dungeons at us, and to pay homage to the original Zelda. It wasn't executed all that well for the reasons you gave, though your "rupee hoardings" criticism doesn't become an issue if you find all of the rupee bag upgrades as soon as they become available.

snippet.textDisplay: I have to say it's hard to pick a favorite Zelda game, but this one is in the top 3 for me. The ocean had an amazingly epic feel to it that I can't truly attach to most other games and it was actually quite technologically marvelous. Plus the soundtrack is still one of my favorites along with the cel-shaded style. I like both it and the more "realistic" style equally.
snippet.textOriginal: I have to say it's hard to pick a favorite Zelda game, but this one is in the top 3 for me. The ocean had an amazingly epic feel to it that I can't truly attach to most other games and it was actually quite technologically marvelous. Plus the soundtrack is still one of my favorites along with the cel-shaded style. I like both it and the more "realistic" style equally.

snippet.textDisplay:
Both OoT and MM are on the Wii's Virtual Console, so you can play them using either a Gamecube controller or a Classic Controller.  The graphics look a little bit better than they do on the N64.

OoT was recently remade for the 3DS with fully updated graphics (and a few other changes), so that's another option.
snippet.textOriginal:
Both OoT and MM are on the Wii's Virtual Console, so you can play them using either a Gamecube controller or a Classic Controller.  The graphics look a little bit better than they do on the N64.

OoT was recently remade for the 3DS with fully updated graphics (and a few other changes), so that's another option.

snippet.textDisplay:
true it has its flaws but it's awesome and stands out for some reasons IMHO:
- technical brilliance, due to it's cell shading it looks better than TP and SS in native resolution and when upscaled
- best facial expression ever in a Zelda game. Full range from hilarious to heart breaking
- Forsaken Fortress! The first visit is a sneaky one like you are solid snake, the second time it's like you kick in the door and wreck the whole thing.
snippet.textOriginal:
true it has its flaws but it's awesome and stands out for some reasons IMHO:
- technical brilliance, due to it's cell shading it looks better than TP and SS in native resolution and when upscaled
- best facial expression ever in a Zelda game. Full range from hilarious to heart breaking
- Forsaken Fortress! The first visit is a sneaky one like you are solid snake, the second time it's like you kick in the door and wreck the whole thing.

snippet.textDisplay: At least the Water Temple was a challenge, unlike pretty much ALL of WW.  I agree with SD: solving the dungeons is probably my favorite aspect of the Zelda series, and WW's dungeons were far too easy and very forgettable.  What they did with combat, though, was fantastic.
snippet.textOriginal: At least the Water Temple was a challenge, unlike pretty much ALL of WW.  I agree with SD: solving the dungeons is probably my favorite aspect of the Zelda series, and WW's dungeons were far too easy and very forgettable.  What they did with combat, though, was fantastic.

snippet.textDisplay: I still don't get the problem people have with the water temple. Sure the need to put on the boots is kind of annoying but the rest is designed brilliantly in a non-linear fashion and it's also contains the legendary (however unexplained iirc) fight against dark Link.
snippet.textOriginal: I still don't get the problem people have with the water temple. Sure the need to put on the boots is kind of annoying but the rest is designed brilliantly in a non-linear fashion and it's also contains the legendary (however unexplained iirc) fight against dark Link.

snippet.textDisplay: Yesssss I've been thinking about this for a month. Like, a month ago, I realized that WW was almost 10 years old and I was like "holy crap, I'm old if one of my favorite games today came out when I was 9!" It certainly doesn't feel like the GC era was that long ago, even when I know the Wii era started 6 years ago.

snippet.textDisplay:
I loved the sense of exploration, I vividly remember all the dungeons, loved the music, the characters, this is my #2 Zelda game and #10 game of all time.
It'd be my #1 Zelda and probably in my top 3 games of all time if not for a single but drastic game destroying flaw...that freaking Triforce piece quest. Between Tingle, insane rupee hoardings, and the most random searching for stuff imaginable, that quest is untolerable. Remove that quest, and this game would be perfect for me.
snippet.textOriginal:
I loved the sense of exploration, I vividly remember all the dungeons, loved the music, the characters, this is my #2 Zelda game and #10 game of all time.
It'd be my #1 Zelda and probably in my top 3 games of all time if not for a single but drastic game destroying flaw...that freaking Triforce piece quest. Between Tingle, insane rupee hoardings, and the most random searching for stuff imaginable, that quest is untolerable. Remove that quest, and this game would be perfect for me.

snippet.textDisplay: Wind Waker came out exactly 10 years ago. As far as I'm concerned,﻿ this game is a flawed masterpiece. The ocean and all the islands gives a sense of exploration that's still hardly﻿ matched. And it's all seamless, no loadings between the ocean and the islands. The cel shaded graphics still look awesome today. Unfortunately, I found the dungeons mostly forgettable, which is why I can't say this is my favorite 3D Zelda.
snippet.textOriginal: Wind Waker came out exactly 10 years ago. As far as I'm concerned,﻿ this game is a flawed masterpiece. The ocean and all the islands gives a sense of exploration that's still hardly﻿ matched. And it's all seamless, no loadings between the ocean and the islands. The cel shaded graphics still look awesome today. Unfortunately, I found the dungeons mostly forgettable, which is why I can't say this is my favorite 3D Zelda.
